title: AAQ: Is it offensive to consider Shiva as a demigod? | HH Stoka Krishna Swami
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So now if we consider Shiva as a demigod, Devata, subordinate to Vishnu or Krishna, will it become an offence? No.
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the question of whether considering Shiva as subordinate to Vishnu or Krishna is offensive, stating that it is not.

segments.key_quote: But greater than Brahma is Shiva because Shiva is not a Jeeva.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the hierarchy among Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, highlighting their roles as permanent governors and emphasizing Shiva's superiority over Brahma because Shiva is not a Jeeva (living entity).

segments.key_quote: So Shiva's birth is like Krishna's birth.
segments.summary: The speaker compares Shiva's birth to Krishna's, describing both as transcendental, and reiterates that Shiva is not a Jeeva, unlike Brahma and other Devatas.

segments.key_quote: Vishnu never comes in contact with material energy.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Vishnu is superior to Shiva because Vishnu never comes into contact with material energy, and emphasizes that only Vishnu possesses unlimited power among the Devatas.

segments.key_quote: She is the energy through which this material world is created, maintained and destroyed.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces Durga Devi as Vishnu Maya, the energy through which the material world is created, maintained, and destroyed, and mentions that the Devi Purana describes her glories.

segments.key_quote: Durga is not independent in creating, maintaining and destroying. She is always subordinate to Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that Durga Devi acts as an agency executing Krishna's will through Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, who direct creation, maintenance, and destruction, respectively.

segments.key_quote: Energy is manifest as the three gunas.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the three gunas (Satva, Rajas, Tamas) as the energy of material nature, contrasting them with the eight material elements (five gross and three subtle) described in the Bhagavad Gita.

segments.key_quote: Those gunas are directed by Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva according to the will of Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker describes how the three gunas drive changes in the material creation, directed by Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva according to Krishna's will, and how the body, influenced by the gunas, binds living entities to the material world.

segments.key_quote: Durga Devi is not independent in controlling anybody. She controls exactly according to the laws. Those laws are laws of God.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a jail superintendent (Durga Devi) enforcing the laws of a higher authority (Krishna) to illustrate how Durga Devi controls the material world according to Krishna's laws, emphasizing that Krishna is the ultimate controller.
